Claim: pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food.
Explaination: Speaking to The Quint, Dr Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist said that viruses do not have pH values.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food.

Explanation:Speaking to The Quint, Dr Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist said that viruses do not have pH values.

https://www.thequint.com/news/webqoof/no-ph-value-of-covid-19-experts-deny-its-link-with-alkaline-foods-fact-check

Claim: “A patent on this ‘new’ coronavirus expired on the 22nd (of January), today”.
Explaination: As noted above, the patent for the vaccine for this new Wuhan strain did not expire on January 22, 2020. That patent is related to the SARS epidemic, which killed more than 800 people after it broke out in China in 2002.
Label: False
html:
Claim: “A patent on this ‘new’ coronavirus expired on the 22nd (of January), today”.

Explanation:As noted above, the patent for the vaccine for this new Wuhan strain did not expire on January 22, 2020. That patent is related to the SARS epidemic, which killed more than 800 people after it broke out in China in 2002.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471529-fake-news-patent-for-coronavirus-that-expired-is-not-for-new-strain-killing-people-in-china.html?check=1

Claim: Fire triggered by gas tanker leak near Delhi’s Shahdara Mor.
Explaination: Video is not from Delhi but Lahore's Shahdara Mor in Pakistan.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: Fire triggered by gas tanker leak near Delhi’s Shahdara Mor.

Explanation:Video is not from Delhi but Lahore's Shahdara Mor in Pakistan.

https://aajtak.intoday.in/story/fact-check-was-this-major-accident-averted-due-to-lockdown-in-delhi-1-1175380.html

Claim: The 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.

Explanation:Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/feb/26/viral-image/book-end-days-described-illness-2020-not-wuhan-400/

Claim: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.

Explanation:Please click the link to read the full article

http://www.ecuadorchequea.com/las-mentiras-sobre-el-covid-19-en-ecuador/?fbclid=IwAR3bwAz0dMLw03No-V2hs3mNm5Nvl8V_p0AnNV7GbLCEh9do16WHgMrsBiE

Claim: Mongolia donates 30,000 sheep to China during the coronavirus epidemic.
Explaination: The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on Feb 27, 2020.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Mongolia donates 30,000 sheep to China during the coronavirus epidemic.

Explanation:The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on Feb 27, 2020.

https://factcheck.afp.com/these-sheep-videos-were-published-online-mongolia-announced-donation-china

Claim: Video of “the market of terror, where the coronavirus originated”.
Explaination: The video was transmitted by most of the Macedonian media, although it is false. The truth is that this video is not of a market in Wuhan, nor anywhere in China, but it is of a market in Indonesia. When you play the video you can see the name of the market in large letters, i.e. Pasar Estream Langowan, and when you search, if you do not know where Langowan is, you will find out that it is in Indonesia, not in China. The falseness of this video was also noted by the AFP FactCheck and Faktly.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Video of “the market of terror, where the coronavirus originated”.

Explanation:The video was transmitted by most of the Macedonian media, although it is false. The truth is that this video is not of a market in Wuhan, nor anywhere in China, but it is of a market in Indonesia. When you play the video you can see the name of the market in large letters, i.e. Pasar Estream Langowan, and when you search, if you do not know where Langowan is, you will find out that it is in Indonesia, not in China. The falseness of this video was also noted by the AFP FactCheck and Faktly.

https://truthmeter.mk/the-market-of-terror-is-in-indonesia-not-in-wuhan/

Claim: Viral claims propagating UNICEF message about coronavirus.
Explaination: Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, Communication Specialist of UNICEF Sri Lanka confirmed that “these messages are NOT UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE” and that an official communication regarding the same would be published via UNICEF’s social media channels.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Viral claims propagating UNICEF message about coronavirus.

Explanation:Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, Communication Specialist of UNICEF Sri Lanka confirmed that “these messages are NOT UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE” and that an official communication regarding the same would be published via UNICEF’s social media channels.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/english/fact-check-truth-behind-the-viral-unicef-message-about-coronavirus/

Claim: Video shows Chinese police crackdown on coronavirus patients.
Explaination: The video actually dates back to August 2019 when anti-government protests were happening in Hong Kong. The visuals pertain to an incident of police crackdown at Prince Edward station in Kowloon where the police personnel and riot police arrived after reports of a tussle between pro-government and anti-government protesters.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Video shows Chinese police crackdown on coronavirus patients.

Explanation:The video actually dates back to August 2019 when anti-government protests were happening in Hong Kong. The visuals pertain to an incident of police crackdown at Prince Edward station in Kowloon where the police personnel and riot police arrived after reports of a tussle between pro-government and anti-government protesters.

https://www.thequint.com/news/webqoof/video-from-hong-kong-painted-as-police-action-on-covid-19-suspects

Claim: Post says “sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.”
Explaination: Although it is not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Post says “sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.”

Explanation:Although it is not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/03/facebook-posts/hand-sanitizer-can-be-used-prevent-coronavirus-inf/

Claim: Coronavirus is fake or a made-up ploy by 5G.
Explaination: This is one of many similar conspiracy theories.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus is fake or a made-up ploy by 5G.

Explanation:This is one of many similar conspiracy theories.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/fact-check-coronavirus-is-not-fake-is-not-a-coverup-to-allow-5g-deployment.html

Claim: Passengers at Delhi airport got agitated Wednesday morning as their passports were withheld by airport authorities.
Explaination: This incident took place a few days back at IGIA in relation to mandatory coronavirus screening
Label: half true
html:
Claim: Passengers at Delhi airport got agitated Wednesday morning as their passports were withheld by airport authorities.

Explanation:This incident took place a few days back at IGIA in relation to mandatory coronavirus screening

https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-know-the-truth-behind-viral-video-of-passenger-agitation-at-delhi-airport-1657181-2020-03-19

Claim: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.

Explanation:Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3472015-fact-check-obama-family-not-flown-to-private-safe-island.html

Claim: The World Health Organization is offering free internet for the public to access information about COVID-19.
Explaination: A link circulating on WhatsApp claiming that the World Health Organization is offering free internet to help people access information on COVID-19 is a hoax.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The World Health Organization is offering free internet for the public to access information about COVID-19.

Explanation:A link circulating on WhatsApp claiming that the World Health Organization is offering free internet to help people access information on COVID-19 is a hoax.

https://pesacheck.org/hoax-this-post-claiming-that-the-world-health-organization-is-offering-free-internet-is-fake-190dec85995e?source=rss----ab41f21aa9a9---4

Claim: “When using a medical mask, you’re supposed to wear the white side out when you’re not sick.”
Explaination: Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.
Label: False
html:
Claim: “When using a medical mask, you’re supposed to wear the white side out when you’re not sick.”

Explanation:Global health agencies and medical mask producers agree that the colored side of the mask should always be worn on the outside.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/feb/14/facebook-posts/medical-masks-should-be-worn-colored-side-out/

Claim: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.
Explaination: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.

Explanation:This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3472009-Fact-Check-Walmart-NOT-Closing-Stores-At-Present-Time.html

Claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter which claim it shows that packets of spice included in Sri Lankan government ration kits during the COVID-19 lockdown were branded with a local political party’s logo. The posts allege that the photo is evidence vulnerable people are being exploited during the pandemic for political gain.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; both the manufacturer and retailer told AFP that it has used the logo on its packaging since at least 2007; the logo is not identical to the cited political party’s electoral symbol, which the party adopted in 2016.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter which claim it shows that packets of spice included in Sri Lankan government ration kits during the COVID-19 lockdown were branded with a local political party’s logo. The posts allege that the photo is evidence vulnerable people are being exploited during the pandemic for political gain.

Explanation:The claim is misleading; both the manufacturer and retailer told AFP that it has used the logo on its packaging since at least 2007; the logo is not identical to the cited political party’s electoral symbol, which the party adopted in 2016.

https://factcheck.afp.com/sri-lankan-spice-manufacturer-said-it-has-used-logo-2007-years-political-party-was-established

Claim: A photo of a room lined with coffins shows Italian nationals killed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photo actually shows coffins for a group of dead migrants at an Italian airport in October 2013 after their boat sank off the coast of Italy.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A photo of a room lined with coffins shows Italian nationals killed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.

Explanation:The claim is false; the photo actually shows coffins for a group of dead migrants at an Italian airport in October 2013 after their boat sank off the coast of Italy.

https://factcheck.afp.com/photo-shows-coffins-dead-migrants-after-boat-capsized-coast-italy-2013

Claim: A photo of a young boy has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and various websites alongside a claim that it shows a 13-year-old who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in the UK in 2020.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photograph has circulated in reports since 2017 about a teenager who died in Ireland.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A photo of a young boy has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and various websites alongside a claim that it shows a 13-year-old who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in the UK in 2020.

Explanation:The claim is false; the photograph has circulated in reports since 2017 about a teenager who died in Ireland.

https://factcheck.afp.com/photo-has-circulated-reports-about-irish-teenager-who-died-2017

Claim: If Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: Buckingham Palace gave statement confirming she was in good health.
Label: False
html:
Claim: If Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.

Explanation:Buckingham Palace gave statement confirming she was in good health.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/03/fact-check-queen-elizabeth-ii-did-not-test-positive-for-coronavirus.html

Claim: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
Explaination: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.

Explanation:Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

https://factcheck.afp.com/major-disease-outbreaks-are-not-tied-us-election-years

Claim: Muslims are licking their plates to spread coronavirus and infect more people with the virus.
Explaination: The video is from three years ago depicting a Dawoodi Bohra practice of licking the plate clean so as to prevent any food from being wasted before washing and is not linked to the coronavirus outbreak.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Muslims are licking their plates to spread coronavirus and infect more people with the virus.

Explanation:The video is from three years ago depicting a Dawoodi Bohra practice of licking the plate clean so as to prevent any food from being wasted before washing and is not linked to the coronavirus outbreak.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/false-video-shows-muslims-licking-utensils-to-spread-coronavirus-7477

Claim: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.
Explaination: The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: Coronavirus fears in Germany result in large crowds outside the supermarket.

Explanation:The viral video is 9 years old and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/panic-buying-germany-viral-video-shopping-ration-aldi-store-1657875-2020-03-20

Claim: The new coronavirus outbreak is linked to eating bats.
Explaination: Bats are known natural reservoirs for coronaviruses. However, many other animals, such as civet cats and snakes, can also carry these viruses. There is currently not enough evidence to conclude that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak resulted from people eating bats in Wuhan, China.
Label: No evidence
html:
Claim: The new coronavirus outbreak is linked to eating bats.

Explanation:Bats are known natural reservoirs for coronaviruses. However, many other animals, such as civet cats and snakes, can also carry these viruses. There is currently not enough evidence to conclude that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak resulted from people eating bats in Wuhan, China.

https://healthfeedback.org/claimreview/no-conclusive-evidence-to-link-consumption-of-bats-with-the-wuhan-coronavirus-outbreak/

Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
Explaination: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.

Explanation:A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.

https://factcheck.afp.com/hoax-report-circulates-cristiano-ronaldo-will-convert-his-hotels-coronavirus-hospitals
